reference.shortdesc: This topic documents the common definitions for attributes that appear within the DITA DTDs, and provides the content for reuse within the individual element descriptions of the DITA Language Reference .

section.p: Writers, please ensure that explanations are generic in nature. For example, references to specific instances of SGML such as DocBook or IBMIDDoc may not be meaningful to all readers. To avoid naming specific products, refer to them generically as "validating XML editors," and so on. Not all DITA users will implement DITA the same way or have the same markup language background when reading DITA documentation!

draft-comment.note: Use <element> and attr for future domain specialization. (Don has been using element and attribute)

section.note: All DITA linking attributes defined as allowing URLs are defined as CDATA but should follow standard URL syntax (CDATA is used for now because DTDs cannot enforce a URL datatype). They are used literally in transforms, therefore the integrity of the link is up to the author.

li.ph: This is a property attribute which supports conditional processing for filtering or flagging.
If no value is specified, but the attribute is specified on an ancestor within a map or within the related-links section, the value will inherit from the closest ancestor.
The attribute takes a space delimited set of values.

The attribute takes a space delimited set of values. However, when acting as a container for generalized attributes, the content model will be more complex; that model is documented in the "attribute generalization" section of the DITA architectural specification.
This element is for runtime resolution of references, and is for navigation only. It is currently only supported by Eclipse output.

ul.li: Not intended for direct use by authors.
This element is part of the DITA highlighting domain.
This element is part of the DITA programming domain, a special set of DITA elements designed to document programming tasks, concepts and reference information.
This element is part of the DITA software domain, a special set of DITA elements designed to document software tasks, concepts and reference information.

section.note: SGML users may recognize that this is very similar to the conref mechanism in SGML (call CONLOC in IBMIDDoc) that uses only an empty start tag to indicate the placement of the referenced element. However, the rules of XML do not allow us to do conref as easily as the SGML standard permitted. Even when you have a conref attribute to pull in content, the element using conref must be valid within the document. In the case of a table, for example, the table element requires a tgroup child, which requires tbody, which requires at least one row, which requires at least one entry. In addition, the tgroup element requires the cols attribute to be specified. You will have to insert all of these elements in your source file, even though they will be discarded during processing. Validating editors will insert all of the required elements, although you may still need to ensure that required attributes contain at least a throwaway value.

Pertaining to the following declaration in topic.mod:<!ELEMENT topic (%title;, (%titlealts;)?, (%shortdesc;)?, (%prolog;)?, %body;, (%related-links;)?, (%topic-info-types;)* )> if the parameter entity topic-info-types in topic.dtd were declared as<!ENTITY % topic-info-types "no-topic-nesting">then the resulting authoring DTD would not allow the nesting of any child topics. As far as the DTD is concerned, this empty element takes the place of any nested topics. Using a null value for a parameter entity value is not allowed in DTD syntax, therefore the architecture provides this empty element as a required token in the syntax.

strow.stentry: This attribute has not been documented yet
A set of related attributes, described at
A set of related attributes, described at
A set of related attributes, described at
A set of related attributes, described at
%select-atts; (props, base, platform, product, audience, otherprops, importance, rev, status)
A set of related attributes, described at
%topicref-atts; (collection-type, type, scope, locktitle, format, linking, toc, print, search, chunk)
A set of related attributes. See .
%topicref-atts-no-toc; (collection-type, type, scope, locktitle, format, linking, toc, print, search, chunk)
A related set of attributes. See .
A set of related attributes, described at
A set of related attributes, described at , but without the importance attribute
Controls the horizontal alignment of an image when placement is specified as "break." Allowable values (processor-validated) are: left, right, center, and current.align attributeimage

Describes the alignment of text in a table column. Allowable values are: left Indicates left alignment of the text.
right Indicates right alignment of the text.
center Indicates center alignment of the text.
justify Justifies the contents to both the left and the right.
-dita-use-conref-target See for more information. align attribute

Alternative text that describes the image to provide accessibility to page readers, or provides a text description when an image cannot be displayed by the user's software.alt attribute The alt attribute is deprecated; use the alt element instead.

Identifies a location within another map file where this map will be anchored (added at runtime, using Eclipse navigation integration). For example, anchorref="map1.ditamap/a1" causes this map to be pulled into the location of the anchor point a1 in the other map1.ditamap.anchorref attribute
Contains the name of the application that will use the resource id to identify the topic.appname attribute

Specifies a space-separated list of URLs indicating resources needed by the object. These resources may include those URLs specified by the classid and data attributes. Preloading these resources usually results in faster loadtimes for objects. The URLs in the list should be relative to the URL specified in the codebase attribute.archive attribute

Indicates the intended audience for the element.
audience attribute
Designates the originator of the draft comment.author attribute

Specifies what character is used for the footnote link, for example a number or an alpha character. The attribute may also specify a short string of characters. When no callout value is specified, footnotes are numbered.callout attribute

alignment character
Default source for entry elements starting in this column. If character alignment is specified, the value is the single alignment character source for any implied char values for entry immediately in this column. A value of "" (the null string) means there is no aligning character.char attribute

horizontal offset of alignment character when align=char
Default source for entry elements starting in this column. For character alignment on an entry in the column, horizontal character offset is the percent of the current column width to the left of the (left edge of the) alignment character.
This value should be number, greater than 0 and less than or equal to 100.charoff attribute

chunk attributeWhen a set of topics is transformed using a map, the chunk attribute allows multi-topic documents to be broken into smaller files, and multiple individual topics to be combined into larger combined documents.
For a detailed description of the chunk attribute and its usage see the section on Chunking in Chapter 4 of the DITA 1.1 Architectural Specification.

Not for use by authors. If an editor displays class attribute values, do not edit them. The class attribute supports specialization. Its predefined values allow DITA tools to work correctly with ranges of related content. In a generalized DITA document the class attribute value in the generalized instance may differ from the default value for the class attribute for the element as given in the DTD or schema.class attribute

stentry.i: Default value differs for each element

strow.stentry: Contains a URL that specifies the location of an object's implementation. It can be used together with the data attribute which is specified relative to the value of the codebase attribute.classid attribute

Specifies the base path (a URL) used for resolving the URL values given for classid, data, and archive attributes. If codebase is not set, the default is the base URL of the current document.codebase attribute

Indicates the content type for the data specified by the classid attribute. This attribute should be set when the classid attribute is set to avoid loading unsupported content types. If this attribute value is not set, the default is the value of the type attribute.codetype attribute

Collection types describe how links relate to each other. A family collection represents a tight grouping in which each of the referenced topics not only relates to the current topic but also relate to each other. Sequence indicates that the order of the child topics is significant; output processors will typically link between them in order. Unordered indicates that the order is not significant. Choice indicates that one of the children should be selected. If no value is specified, processors should treat the default as "unordered", although no default is specified in the DTD. See this topic for more information on the conref value.collection-type attribute
Usage of the collection-type attribute on <reltable> and <relcolspec> is currently undefined, and reserved for future use.
Specifies the table column name in which an entry is found.colname attribute
Indicates the number of a column in the table, counting from the first logical column to the last column.colnum attribute
Indicates the number of columns in a <tgroup> in a table.cols attribute
Column separator. A value of 0 indicates no separators; 1 indicates separators.colsep attribute

Indicates close vertical spacing between the list items. Expanded spacing is the default value. The output result of compact spacing depends on the processor or browser. Allowed values are: yes Indicates compact spacing.
no Indicates expanded spacing.
compact attribute
This attribute is used to reference an ID on a topic that can be reused. See for examples and details about the syntax.
This attribute is used to reference an ID on a map that can be reused. See for examples and details about the syntax.
This attribute is used to reference an ID on content that can be reused. See for examples and details about the syntax.
Conref may be used within a map to reuse portions of a map (such as a topicref branch or relationship table). See for examples and details about the syntax.
The value for the property named in the name attribute.content attribute

Use the copy-to attribute on the <topicref> element to provide a different file name for a particular instance of the topic in the map (for example, to separate out the different versions of the topic, rather than combining them on output). The links and navigation associated with that instance will point to a copy of the topic with the file name you specified.
Use the <linktext> and <shortdesc> in the <topicref>'s <topicmeta> to provide a unique name and short description for the new copy.copy-to attribute

Contains a reference to the location of an object's data. If this attribute is a URL, it is specified relative to the value of the codebase attribute. If this attribute is set, the type attribute should also be set.data attribute

The document creation date. Enter the date as YYYY-MM-DD where YYYY is the year, MM is the month from 01 to 12, and DD is the day from 01-31. See A Summary of the International Standard Date and Time Notation for background.date attribute

When this attribute is set to declare, the current object definition is a declaration only. The object must be instantiated by a later nested object definition referring to this declaration.declare attribute
Status of the draft comment. Values can be issue, open, accepted, rejected, deferred, duplicate, reopened, unassigned, or completed.disposition attribute
Indicates the specialized domains that are included in the DTD or Schema.domains attribute
(topic ui-d) (topic hi-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d)
Indicates the specialized domains that are included in the DTD or Schema.domains attribute
Indicates the specialized domains that are included in the DTD or Schema.domains attribute
Designates the version of the architecture that is in use.DITAArchVersion attribute

Specifies whether or not duplicate links will be filtered out of a linklist. Allowable values are: "yes" (allow duplicate links), or "no" (filter out duplicate links). In general, duplicate links in linklists are preserved.. Note that links are regarded as duplicates only if their content plus all attributes match. duplicates attribute
The attribute value is currently ignored, but should default to yes for links in linklists and no for all other links.

Determines the horizontal placement of the element.
Allowable values are: "page" places the element on the left page margin; "column" aligns the element with the current column margin; "textline" aligns the element with the left margin of the current text line and takes indention into account.
See for more information on the conref value.
For non-paginated output, such as XHTML, some values may not be supported.
In DITA tables, in place of the expanse attribute used by other DITA elements, the pgwide attribute is used in order to conform with the OASIS Exchange Table Model. This attribute has a similar semantic (1=page width; 0=resize to galley or column).expanse attribute

Indicates the level of experience the audience is assumed to possess. Different audiences may have different experience levels with respect to the same topic; for example, a topic may require general knowledge from a programmer, but expert knowledge from a user. Allowable values are: novice A first time user.
general The most common user.
expert An experienced user.
experiencelevel attribute
The date when the information should be retired or refreshed, entered as YYYY-MM-DD, where YYYY is the year, MM is the month from 01 to 12, and DD is the day from 01-31.expiry attribute
The format attribute identifies the format of the resource being cross referenced. See for details on supported values.format attribute

Specifies which portion of a border should surround the element. Allowable values are: top Draw a line before the element
bottom Draw a line after the element
topbot Draw a line both before and after the element
all Draw a box around the element
sides Draw a line at each side of the element
none Don't draw any lines around this element
Some DITA processors or output formats may not be able to support all values.frame attribute
The publication or general availability (GA) date, entered as YYYY-MM-DD, where YYYY is the year, MM is the month from 01 to 12, and DD is the day from 01-31.golive attribute

Indicates the vertical dimension for the resulting image display. If necessary, the image is scaled to the specified size. The value of this attribute is a real number optionally following by a unit of measure from the set of pc, pt, px, in, cm, mm, em (picas, points, pixels, inches, centimeters, millimeters, and ems respectively). The default unit is px (pixels). Possible values include: "5", "5in", and "10.5cm". If a height value is specified and no width value is specified, the width will be scaled by the same factor as the height. If both a height value and width value are specified, some implementations may not be able to scale the two directions by a different factor and may therefore ignore one of the two values.height attribute

Indicates the vertical dimension for the resulting object display. If necessary, the object is scaled to the specified size. If a height value is specified and no width value is specified, the width will be scaled by the same factor as the height. height attribute

A hyperlink to an external Web page (URL) or other non-DITA resource, or to another DITA topic in the same file or in another file. The format attribute identifies the format of the target. Non-DITA targets use standard URL syntax. DITA topics are targetted as follows:Target elsewhere in the same file: href="#topicid" First topic in different file: href="filename.dita" Specific topic in different file: href="filename.dita#topicid"
If the URL contains an ampersand character, the ampersand symbol (&) should be used to indicate that characterhref attribute

A hyperlink to an external Web page (URL) or other non-DITA resource, to another DITA topic in the same file or in another file, or to a specific element inside a DITA topic. The format attribute identifies the format of the target. Non-DITA targets use standard URL syntax. DITA content is targetted as follows:Target elsewhere in the same file: href="#topicID" href="#topicID/elemID Target in a different file: href="filename.dita#topicID" href="fname.dita#topicID/elemID"Elements inside a topic need to have their location scoped by the containing topic's ID. Only the id of the target element and the topic that contains it matter: id's on any other containing elements (for example an id on the <body> element) are not part of the link syntax.
If the URL contains an ampersand character, the ampersand symbol (&) should be used to indicate that characterhref attribute

A pointer to the resource represented by the <topicref>. References to DITA content cannot be below the topic level: that is, you cannot reference individual elements inside a topic. References to content other than DITA topics should use the format attribute to identify the kind of resource being referenced.href attribute

Points to a manual listing for the current element. If no href is specified, processors may choose to generate an appropriate listing for this element. All of the book listings operate in a similar manner; for example, <toc href="toc.dita"/> points to a topic which contains a manual table of contents, while <toc/> indicates that a processor should generate the table of contents. href attribute
Points to the target syntax note (<synnote>), which must be in the same syntax diagram. Use standard DITA href syntax for targetting the element: href="#topicid/synnoteid"href attribute

A hyperlink representing a resource that defines the person or company named in the parent element. For example, you could use this attribute to cite the URL for the named entity's home page. The href attribute identifies the destination of the resource using conventional URL syntax.href attributedefining

A reference to a syntax diagram fragment element. The referenced fragment should be in the same diagram as the fragref element. The href attribute uses conventional URL syntax to point to the ID of the matching syntax diagram fragment:href="#topicid/fragmentid"href attributefragref
The relative path or URL to the image. The href attribute uses conventional URL syntax to point to the resource:href="../images/construction.gif"href attributeimage

A hyperlink representing a bibliographic citation to resources that can be accessed by browsers (meaning a URL). The href attribute identifies the destination of the resource using conventional URL syntax.href attributelq
A pointer to the external resource from which the present resource is derived. The href attribute identifies the destination of the resource using conventional URL syntax.href attributesource
This ID enables topics to be referenced uniquely by topicrefs in DITA maps.id attribute
An anchor point. This ID is the target for references by href and conref attributes, and for external applications that refer to DITA content.id attribute

Provides an integration point that another map may reference in order to insert its navigation into the current navigation tree. The anchorref attribute on a map may be used to reference this attribute.
This ID is the target for references by conref attributes, to allow build-time integration of maps.id attribute
The value used by a specific application to identify the topic.id attribute
The id of the parameter.id attribute
This attribute may be used for debugging purposes, for example to identify which map a link was generated from.id attributemap

The attribute indicates whether this item in a syntax diagram is optional or required. Output processors may indicate this designation in a generated diagram. See this topic for more information on the conref value.importance attributedelimfragrefrepsep

The attribute indicates whether this item in a syntax diagram is optional, required, or default. Output processors may indicate this designation in a generated diagram. See for more information on the conref value.importance attributevarkwdopersepSyntax groups

A range of values that describe an importance or priority attributed to an element. For example, in steps of a task, the attribute indicates whether a step is optional or required. importance attribute
obsolete | deprecated | optional | default | low | normal | high | recommended | required | urgent | -dita-use-conref-target
Describes whether the current step or substep is optional or required. Output processors may (but need not) highlight steps that are optional or required.importance attributestep, substep

Indicates the high-level task the audience for the topic is trying to accomplish. Different audiences may read the same topic in terms of different high-level tasks; for example, an administrator may read the topic while administering, while a programmer may read the same topic while customizing. Allowable values are: installing, customizing, administering, programming, using, maintaining, troubleshooting, evaluating, planning, migrating, other, -dita-use-conref-target.job attribute
installing | customizing | administering | programming | using | maintaining | troubleshooting | evaluating | planning | migrating | other | -dita-use-conref-target

Defines the column that will be used for row headings. No value indicates no key column. When present, the numerical value causes the specified column to be highlighted as a vertical header.keycol attribute
Defines the column that will be used for row headings. By default, the first column is used. To indicate that no column in the table is the key column, set the attribute to 0.
The keyref attribute is reserved for future use. The OASIS DITA Technical Committee expects to finish designing this attribute in the next release of the DITA standard.keyref attribute
Provides a key that a process can use to identify a higher-level index term that the current index term should be added under. Currently not implemented in the DITA Open Toolkit.keyref attribute
Currently not implemented in DITA processors. Provides a key that a process can use to look up the location of the cited material, and potentially create a link to it.keyref attributecite
Provides a key that a process can use to look up the path to author information, and potentially create a link to it. Currently not implemented in the DITA Open Toolkit.keyref attributeauthor

Provides a key that a process can use to associate the <cmd> with another task that provides more details for that particular step. Currently not implemented in the DITA Open Toolkit.keyref attributecmd

Provides a key that a process can use to associate the <cmdname> with the reference topic for the command, if the command name itself isn't sufficient. Currently not implemented in the DITA Open Toolkit.keyref attributecmdname
Provides a key that a process can use to associate the <dt> with a topic elsewhere (such as a related reference or concept). Currently not implemented in the DITA Open Toolkit.keyref attributedt
Provides a key that a process can use to refer to the <image> by a key rather than referencing it directly. Currently not implemented in the DITA Open Toolkit.keyref attributeimage
Provides a key that a process can use to identify the indexterm which the current location should be added to. Currently not implemented in the DITA Open Toolkit.keyref attributeindextermref

Provides a key that a process can use to associate the <keyword> with another topic that provides more details for that particular keyword. Currently not implemented in the DITA Open Toolkit.keyref attributekeyword

Provides a key that a process can use to associate the <kwd> with another topic that provides more details for that particular keyword. Currently not implemented in the DITA Open Toolkit.keyref attributekwd

Defines some specific linking characteristics of a topic's current location in the map. targetonly A topic can only be linked to and cannot link to other topics.
sourceonly A topic cannot be linked to but can link to other topics.
normal A topic can be linked to and can link to other topics. Use this to override the linking value of a parent topic.
none A topic cannot be linked to or link to other topics.
linking attribute
Indicates whether any of the meta information should be replaced by meta information in the referenced topic.lockmeta attribute

This attribute makes sure the navtitle attribute is used if it is present; if locktitle isn't set to yes, the navtitle attribute is ignored and text is retrieved from the target
yes The navtitle in the map is used.
no Default. The navtitle or title of the topic is used.
locktitle attribute

A reference to a textual description of the graphic or object. This attribute supports creating accessible content. It uses standard href syntax. This may be a reference to another DITA topic, or to a non-DITA description. For examples of how this attribute is used in output, see this this topic on long descriptions.longdescref attribute

Identifies the map, if any, from which the contained links are derived. This value is automatically generated by the same process that creates the links from the map, as a way to identify which map the links came from. If the <linklist> or <linkpool> is manually created by the author, there is no need to use this attribute.mapkeyref attribute

Specifies the URL (local filename, at least) of the map file to reference. It may point to a DITA map, or to a file that is appropriate for your output format (such as XML TOC file for Eclipse output).mapref attribute
Indicates when the product described in this topic was last modified.modification attribute
The last modification date, entered as YYYY-MM-DD, where YYYY is the year, MM is the month from 01 to 12, and DD is the day from 01-31.modified attribute
Specifies the number of additional rows to add in a vertical span. morerows attribute
Defines a unique name for the object.name attribute
The name of the property whose state is being described.name attribute
The name of the event represented by this element.name attribute
The name of the parameter.name attribute
The name of the metadata property.name attribute
Used to associate the audience element with values used in the audience attributename attributeaudience
Specifies the last logical column that is included in a horizontal span.nameend attribute
Specifies the first logical column that is included in a horizontal span.namest attribute
Specifies the title of the topic as it will appear in navigation or tables of contents generated from the map.navtitle attribute
Specifies a title that will appear in navigation or tables of contents generated from the map.navtitle attributetopichead
If the job attribute value is "other" the value of this attribute is used to identify a kind of job other than the default ones provided by the job attribute. otherjob attribute
This attribute can be used for any other properties that might be needed to describe an audience, or to provide selection criteria for the element. otherprops attribute
Indicates an alternate role. This value is used when the role attribute is set to other.otherrole attribute

Indicates an alternate audience type, when the type is not available in the type attribute value list. This value is used as the user-provided audience when the type attribute value is set to "other."othertype attribute

Indicates an alternate note type, when the type is not available in the type attribute value list. This value is used as the user-provided note title when the type attribute value is set to "other."othertype attributenote

Names a role that the element is playing. The role must be consistent with the basic semantic and expectations for the element. In particular, the outputclass attribute can be used for styling during output processing; HTML output will typically preserve outputclass for CSS processing.

Indicates whether an image should be displayed inline or separated from the surrounding text. The processing default is inline. Allowable values are: inline or break. See for more information on the conref value.placement attribute
Indicates operating system and hardware. platform attribute

Specifies whether the topic should be included in a portable document format (PDF) file. yes Include the topic in a PDF file.
no Do not include the topic in a PDF file.
printonly Directs processing to skip the parent topic for non-print outputs of map.
print attribute
Contains the name of the product to which the topic applies. product attribute
This attribute is deprecated. It may be removed in the future.query attribute
Designates columns that contain references, and are candidates for automated linking. Columns are identified by a space-delimited list of numbers (for example: 1 3).refcols attribute
The title of the document or topic being quoted.reftitle attribute

A relative value to specify the width of a column in relationship to the width of the other columns. The values are totaled and made a percent. For example: relcolwidth="1* 2* 3*" causes widths of 16.7%, 33.3%, and 66.7%. relcolwidth="90* 150*" causes width of 37.5% and 62.5%.relcolwidth attribute
Contains the product release identifier.release attribute
Indicates the element that the contents of the required-cleanup element were mapped from (provides an idea about what the new intent should be).remap attribute
Indicates revision level of an element. It is useful for flagging outputs based on revision. rev attribute

The role attribute defines the role the target topic plays in relationship with the current topic. For example, in a parent/child relationship, the role would be "parent" when the target is the parent of the current topic, and "child" when the target is the child of the current topic. This structure could be used to sort and classify links at display time. See for information on supported values.
(parent | child | sibling | friend | next | previous | cousin | ancestor | descendant | sample | external | [deprecated] other | -dita-use-conref-target)

This attribute specifies whether the content of the first column in a table contains row headings. In the same way that a column header introduces a table column, the row header introduces the table row. This attribute makes tables whose first column contains row headings more readable on output. Allowable values are: firstcol The first column contains the row headings.
norowheader Indicates that no column contains row headings. This is the processing default.
rowheader attribute
Row separator. A value of 0 indicates no separators; 1 indicates separators.rowsep attribute

Specifies a percentage, selected from an enumerated list, that is used to resize fonts in relation to the normal text size. This attribute is primarily useful for print-oriented display.
The scale attribute provides an acknowledged style-based property directly on DITA elements. For the table and fig elements, the intent of the property is to allow authors to adjust font sizes on the content of the containing element, primarily for print accomodation. An image in these contexts is to be scaled only by its own direct scale property. If not specifically scaled, such an image is unchanged by the scale property of its parent table or fig.scale attribute

Specifies a percentage by which to scale the image in the absence of any specified image height or width; a value of 100 implies that the image should be presented at its intrinsic size. If a value has been specified for this image's height or width attribute (or both), the scale attribute is ignored.scale attribute
NMTOKEN whose value space is an unsigned integer

The scope attribute identifies the closeness of the relationship between the current document and the target resource.
Set scope to local when the resource is part of the current set of content.
Set scope to peer when the resource is part of the current set of content but is not accessible at build time.
Set scope to external when the resource is not part of the current information set and should open in a new browser window.
See for more information on -dita-use-conref-target. The processing default is local. scope attribute

Describes whether the target is available for searching. yes
no
-dita-use-conref-target
search attribute

The specialized entry attribute allows architects of specialized types to define a fixed or default header title for a specialized stentry element. Not intended for direct use by authors.specentry attribute
The specialized title attribute allows architects of specialized types to define a fixed or default title for a specialized element. Not intended for direct use by authors.spectitle attribute
Contains a message to be displayed while an object is loading.standby attribute
The state of the boolean element. Allowable values are: yes nostate attribute
The status of the current element. status attribute
Position the object in tabbing order.tabindex attribute
Describes when the draft comment was created.time attribute
An identifying title for this element.title attribute

An identifying title for the map. May be used or ignored, depending on the capabilities of the display mechanism. Note that in DITA 1.1, the map can include a title element, which is preferred over the title attribute.title attribute
Classification of the trademark. This may used to differentiate different groupings of trademarks.tmclass attribute
The trademark owner, for example "OASIS"tmowner attribute
The trademark type: trademark, registered trademark, or service marktmtype attribute
Specifies whether a topic appears in the table of contents (toc). If the value is not specified locally, but it specified on an ancestor, it will inherit the value of on the ancestor.toc attribute
Specifies whether a topic appears in the table of contents (toc). This value defaults to no for elements such as reltable, which typically cannot appear in the toc.toc attribute

Indicates whether the content of the element should be translated or not. The DITA architectural specification contains a list of each OASIS DITA element and its common processing default for the translate value.translate attribute

Indicates whether the content of the element should be translated or not. Setting to "yes" will override the default. The DITA architectural specification contains a list of each OASIS DITA element and its common processing default for the translate value; because this element uses an actual default, it will always be treated as translate="no" unless overridden as described.
Indicates whether the content attribute of the defined metadata property should be translated or not.translate-content attribute
Describes the target of a cross-reference. See for detailed information on supported values and processing implications.
#IMPLIED (Processed as if the target were of type "topic", or inherited from an ancestor)

Indicates the kind of person for whom the content of the topic is intended. Note that this differs from the type attribute on many other DITA elements. Allowable values are: user A user of the product
purchaser A product purchaser
administrator A product administrator
programmer A programmer
executive An executive
services Someone who provides services related to the product
other Use the value specified by the othertype attribute
type attributeaudience
(user | purchaser | administrator | programmer | executive | services | other | -dita-use-conref-target)

Indicates the primary author of the content. Allowable values are:
creator The primary or original author of the content.
contributor An additional author who is not primary.
type attributeauthor

Indicates the legal status of the copyright holder. Allowable values are: primary The copyright holder with first claim on the copyright
secondary An additional copyright holder who is not primary
type attributecopyright
Defines the type of a note. For example, if the note is a tip, the word Tip is used to draw the reader's attention to it. See for detailed information on supported values and processing implications.
(note | tip | fastpath | restriction | important | remember | attention | caution | danger | other | -dita-use-conref-target)

Indicates the location of the source of the quote. Allowable values are: external the href is to a Web site
internal the href is to a DITA topic
bibliographic the href is to a specialized bibliographic topic. There is not currently a standard bibliographic topic type at OASIS.
type attributelq
Indicates the content type for the data specified by the data attribute. This attribute should be set when the data attribute is set to avoid loading unsupported content types. type attributeobject

This attribute specifies the content type of the resource designated by the value attribute only in the case where valuetype is set to ref. This attribute specifies for the user agent the type of values that will be found at the URI designated by value. type attributeparam

Indicates that a client-side image map is to be used. An image map specifies active geometric regions of an included object and assigns a link to each region. When a link is selected, a document may be retrieved or a program may run on the server.usemap attribute

Indicates the vertical alignment of text in a table entry (cell). Allowable values are: top Align the text to the top of the table entry (cell).
bottom Align the text to the bottom of the table entry (cell).
middle Align the text to the middle of the table entry (cell).
valign attribute
Specifies the value of a run-time parameter specified by the name attribute.value attribute
The state of the property identified by the name attribute.value attribute
Describes the status of this publication. Values are beta, limited, general, and -dita-use-conref-target.value attribute
Describes restrictions on this version of the publication. Values are confidential, restricted, licensed, unclassified, and -dita-use-conref-target.value attribute

Specifies the type of the value attribute. Allowed values are:
data A value of data means that the value will be evaluated and passed to the object's implementation as a string.
ref A value of ref indicates that the value of valuetype is a URL that designates a resource where run-time values are stored. This allows support tools to identify URLs that are given as parameters.
object A value of object indicates that the value of valuetype is an identifier that refers to an object declaration in the document. The identifier must be the value of the ID attribute set for the declared object element. valuetype attribute
Indicates the released version number of the product(s) that the document describes.version attribute

Defines the classifications of viewers allowed to view the document. Allowable values are: internal For internal use only.
classified For a certain group, only.
all The world.
entitled Special folks, only.
view attribute

Indicates the horizontal dimension for the resulting image display. If necessary, the image is scaled to the specified size. If a width value is specified and no height value is specified, the height will be scaled by the same factor as the width. width attribute

Indicates the horizontal dimension for the resulting object display. If necessary, the object is scaled to the specified size. If a width value is specified and no height value is specified, the height will be scaled by the same factor as the width. width attribute

Specifies the language of the element content. When no xml:lang value is supplied, the default value of English is assumed. For example, if there is a note element with the attribute xml:lang set to the value "es," then the label on the note, which normally appears as "Note" will now appear in Spanish as "Nota." The allowed xml:lang values are based on RFC 4646 Tags for Identifying Languages (see W3C: Language tags in HTML and XML).xml:lang attribute

This attribute is provided on <pre>, <lines>, and on elements specialized from them. It ensures that parsers in editors and transforms respect the line-end characters that are part of the data in those elements. It is intended to be part of the default properties of these elements, and not for authors to change or delete.xml:space attribute
The year in YYYY format.year attribute

base attributeAttribute specializationSpecializable attributesA generic attribute that has no specific purpose, but is intended to act as a base for specialized attributes that have a simple value syntax like the conditional processing attributes (one or more alphanumeric values separated by whitespace).
props attributeAttribute specializationSpecializable attributesRoot attribute from which new metadata attributes can be specialized.

Determines the horizontal placement of the element. Supported values are 1 and 0, although these are not mandated by the DTD.
For PDF, the value "1" places the element on the left page margin; "0" aligns the element with the left margin of the current text line and takes indention into account.
For XHTML, the table surrounds the table data. Either value sets the table width to 100%.pgwide attribute
Describes the type of data contained in the value attribute or within the data element. A typical use of datatype will be the identifying URI for an XML Schema datatype.
A set of related attributes, described at .

Specifies the directionality of text: left-to-right (ltr, the processing default) or right-to-left (rtl). See the DITA Architectural Specification for best practices related to this attribute, and other aspects of DITA and translation.dir attribute
Specifies that an index entry is positioned at the beginning of a range. See the description of <indexterm> for more information.
